data.title: Overview of Criminal Psychology
data.text: This chapter introduces the definition, history, basic theories, and research fields of criminal psychology.

items.title: Definition of Criminal Psychology
items.text: Criminal psychology studies criminal behavior and its psychological mechanisms, aiming to understand offenders' psychological traits and motives.

items.title: Historical Development
items.text: Criminal psychology originated in the late 19th century and gradually became an independent discipline alongside developments in psychology and law.

items.title: Main Research Areas
items.text: Including causes of criminal psychology, crime-type analysis, assessment, and intervention.

items.title: Relationship with Other Disciplines
items.text: Criminal psychology is closely related to law, sociology, biology, and other fields, working together to explore crime phenomena.

items.title: Biological Theories
items.text: Exploring genetic and neurophysiological influences on criminal behavior.

items.title: Psychological Theories
items.text: Analyzing the links between personality, cognition, emotions, and criminal behavior.

items.title: Sociological Theories
items.text: Examining how social environment and cultural background shape criminal psychology.

items.title: Integrated Theories
items.text: Combining biological, psychological, and sociological perspectives for a comprehensive explanation of criminal psychology.
